# L1 morphosyntactic anticipation

## Central Swedish

Low tone + singular: _fisken_ 'fish<sub>[SG]</sub>'     
High tone + plural: _fiskar_ 'fish<sub>[PL]</sub>' <font size="-1">     
(Roll et al., 2010)</font>

## Spanish
First syllable stressed + present: _canta_ 's/he sings'     
First syllable unstressed + past: _cantó_ 's/he sang' <font size="-1">     
(Sagarra & Casillas, 2018)</font>

---

# L2 morphosyntactic anticipation

Lexical stress > verb tense, aspect, person, and number

Monolingual speakers of Spanish and advanced L2 Spanish speakers whose L1 is English do it (living in L1 context) <font size="-1">(Sagarra & Casillas, 2018; Lozano et al., 2020)</font>

Factors: 
- L1 transfer and L2 proficiency <font size="-1">(Dupoux et al., 2008; Dussias et al., 2013; Sagarra & Casillas, 2018)</font>
- WM <font size="-1">(Sagarra & Casillas, 2018; Lozano et al., 2020)</font>
- Context <font size="-1">(Beatty-Martínez et al., 2019)</font>

# Models

Phoneme acquisition:
 - Speech Learning Model <font size="-1">(SLM, Flege, 1995)</font>
 - Second Language Linguistic Perception <font size="-1">(L2LP, Escudero, 2005)</font>
 - Perceptual Assimilation Model for Suprasegmentals <font size="-1">(PAM-S, So & Best, 2014)</font>

---

# Research Questions

## Study 1: Linguistic anticipation
	
**RQ1. Do Spanish monolinguals, and intermediate and advanced Mandarin and English learners of Spanish use lexical stress to anticipate verbal suffixes in Spanish (living in L2 context)?**      
**If so, are prediction abilities mediated by verbal WM?**

</br>
--
**H1.** Only monolingual and advanced L2 speakers will anticipate <font size="-1">(Lozano et al., 2019; Sagarra & Casillas, 2018)</font>, but L2 will not reach native-like performance <font size="-1">(Perdomo & Kaan, 2019)</font>.
WM will only affect performance in the L2 groups <font size="-1">(Huettig & Mani, 2016; Otten & van Berkum, 2009; Sagarra & Casillas, 2018)</font>.

---

# Discussion

**Do Spanish monolinguals, and intermediate and advanced Mandarin and English learners of Spanish use lexical stress to anticipate verbal suffixes in Spanish (living in L2 context)?**      
**If so, are prediction abilities mediated by verbal WM?**

- Context matters <font size="-1">(Beatty Martínez et al., 2019)</font>: Intermediate speakers can predict to a certain extent too <font size="-1">(Hed et al., 2019; Schremm et al., 2016 v. Lozano, 2020; Sagarra & Casillas, 2018)</font>

--

- Individual cognitive differences in terms of WM play no role <font size="-1">(e.g., Otten & Van Berkum, 2009; Tanner & Van Hell, 2014)</font>

--

- Function knowledge transfer is more effective than acoustic knowledge transfer

--

- SLM: L1 tone category prevents creation of L2 lexical stress category
- L2LP: perception is different from recognition

---

# Conclusion

- Previous as well as current context matter when learning how to use L2 prosody structures for easier processing of linguistic information and for prediction.
- L2 proficiency and immersion can aid in overcoming L2 acquisition hurdles related to suprasegmentals.
